revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Lotfi Raissi |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1974|04|04}} |birth_place = [[Bab El Oued]], [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]] |death_date = |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Algeria]]n |citizenship = [[Algeria]]n, [[United Kingdom|British]] |other_names = |known_for = Wrongly accused of being involved with the [[9/11]] terrorist attacks |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |party = |boards = |spouse = Sonia |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Lotfi Raissi''' ({{lang-ar|لطفي رئيسي}}, ''Luṭfī Rayissī''; born April 4, 1974), was the first person charged in connection with the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11, 2001, attacks]]. However, in 2003 a British court ruled that the charges against Raissi were without [[evidence]], and that he had no association with the attacks. In April 2010 it was announced that he was eligible for compensation, the amount of which was as yet undecided.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8640659.stm|title=9/11 pilot Lotfi Raissi wins compensation battle|publisher=The BBC|date=April 23, 2010|accessdate=April 23, 2010}} ==Background== Raissi was born and grew up in Bab el Oued, a suburb of [[Algiers]]. In November 1996 he moved to [[Phoenix, Arizona]], USA, to attend [[flight school]], including a 1998 stint at Sawyer School of Aviation a month after [[Hani Hanjour]] quit. In April 2000, when his [[student visa]] expired, he moved back to Algeria and then to [[London]], with his wife Sonia ([[née]] Demolis), whom he had met in the [[United States]]. From June 11–18, 2001, Raissi had apparently visited [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], while [[Ziad Jarrah]] was in the city. {{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2001%2F10%2F04%2FMN102970.DTL |title=Agents of terror leave their mark on Sin City / Las Vegas workers recall the men they can't forget |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=[[Kevin Fagan (journalist)|Kevin Fagan]] |date=2001-10-04 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sfgate.com%2Fcgi-bin%2Farticle.cgi%3Ffile%3D%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2001%2F10%2F04%2FMN102970.DTL&date=2008-08-12 |archivedate=2008-08-12 |df= }} On his way home from the city, he was given a citation for speeding in Arizona. {{cite news | url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2001/Nov-11-Sun-2001/news/17421140.html | title=Hijacker inquiry starting to slow | publisher=[[Las Vegas Review Journal]] | author=Glen Puit | date=2001-11-11 | accessdate=2008-08-12 | quote= | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5a1Jkuxly?url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2001/Nov-11-Sun-2001/news/17421140.html | archivedate=2008-08-12 | deadurl=yes }} ==Implication in 9/11 terrorist attacks== ===Arrest and Investigation=== Raissi was living outside [[Colnbrook]] (near [[Heathrow]]) at the time of the attacks. He was arrested at 3 am on September 21, 2001, when he was taken from his house naked, along with his wife Sonia and his brother. {{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1822228.stm |title=Terror suspect describes jail 'ordeal' |publisher=[[BBC]] |author= |date=2002-02-15 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031206200029/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1822228.stm |archivedate=2003-12-06 |df= }} ''[[The Times]]'' obtained a copy of the [[FBI]]'s initial request for information about Raissi. In it, ''The Times'' asserts, the FBI requested that [[United Kingdom|British]] authorities use discretion, in order not to tip him off that he was under suspicion. Raissi's brother and wife Sonia were released by British police four days after the arrests, although Sonia lost her job working with [[Air France]] and his brother's wife lost her job at [[Heathrow Airport]] as well. World news | The Guardian2002-09-11 {{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/september11/oneyearon/interview/0,12385,788879,00.html | title=Lofti Raissi | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | author= | date=2002-09-11 | accessdate=2008-08-12 | quote= | location=London }} [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.guardian.co.uk%2Fworld%2F2002%2Fsep%2F11%2Fseptember112002.september1147&date=2008-08-12 mirror] From there Raissi was detained for five months at [[Belmarsh Prison]], under suspicion of training the pilots who flew the jet into [[the Pentagon]]. He was also charged with using a "false identity" having gone by the name "'''Fabrice Vincent Algier'''", and for conspiring to help Redouane Dahmani [[Visa fraud|lie on his visa application]]. {{cite news |url=http://news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/terrorism/usraissi112701ind.pdf |title=USA v. Lofti Raissi |publisher= |author= |date=2001-11-27 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |format=PDF |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.findlaw.com%2Fhdocs%2Fdocs%2Fterrorism%2Fusraissi112701ind.pdf&date=2008-08-12 |archivedate=2008-08-12 |df= }} After a week of interrogation US officials, and British prosecutor James Lewis, made an [[extradition]] request; ironically, due to a lack of evidence that he was involved in the September 11 attacks, the only charge he could be held on was lying on his pilot's licence application by not revealing he had undergone knee surgery after a [[tennis]] injury, and a charge for [[shoplifting]] at a London airport dating to 1993. Raissi's attorney was [[Richard Egan (solicitor)|Richard Egan]] {{cite news |url=http://www.tuckerssolicitors.com/show_lawyer.asp?id=41 |title=Richard Egan |publisher= |author= |date= |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060520021654/http://www.tuckerssolicitors.com/show_lawyer.asp?id=41 |archivedate=2006-05-20 |df= }} British prosecutor Arvinder Sambei (who became a director of Amicus Legal Consultants, which is now Sambei, Bridger & Polaine) publicly announced that the FBI had discovered Raissi's name in [[Salem al-Hazmi]]'s rental vehicle; that a raid on Raissi's home had turned up video evidence of him and [[Hani Hanjour]] celebrating together on his computer; that further telephone records confirmed their suspicions that he had trained four of the hijackers in an effort to help support terrorism against U.S. interests, that his pilot logbook was missing all data from March 2000 to June 2001, and stated that they might seek the [[death penalty]]. {{cite news |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2001/Sep-29-Sat-2001/news/17113504.html |title=Algerian accused in Britain of training hijackers |publisher=[[Las Vegas Review Journal]] |author= |date=2001-09-29 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.reviewjournal.com%2Flvrj_home%2F2001%2FSep-29-Sat-2001%2Fnews%2F17113504.html&date=2008-08-12 |archivedate=2008-08-12 |df= }} However once his trial began, they were unable to produce any such evidence. According to ''The Times''; :{| class="wikitable" border="1" |
A video that the FBI claimed showed Mr Raissi with Hani Hanjour, one of the hijackers, was revealed in court to be footage of him with his cousin.
|} On February 12, 2002, Judge [[Timothy Workman]] allowed Raissi to post £10,000 [[bail]] and surrender his passport, after stating that there seemed to be no credibility to the US claims.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1815903.stm|title=Accused pilot released on bail|date=2002-02-12|publisher=[[BBC]]|quote=|author=|accessdate=2016-05-12}} He was formally released from charges on April 21. ===Lawsuits=== In September 2003, Raissi announced he was [[lawsuit|suing]] the [[FBI]] and the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] for $10 million over claims that his life had been ruined by his being branded a [[terrorist]] and that he was unable to find work. The suit, carried by [[Richard Egan (solicitor)|Richard Egan]]{{cite news|title=AWARDS: honour for lawyer who advised man wrongly accused of 11 September involvement |url= https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/news/legal-aid-winners-named/39304.article |accessdate=20 August 2017|date=20 August 2017}} and Jules Carey of [[Tuckers Solicitors]], alleges [[false imprisonment]], [[false arrest]], [[malicious prosecution]], malicious continuation of prosecution, abuse of process, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and [[negligence]] in infliction of emotional distress. [[Amnesty International]]'s Paul Hoffman was one of the lawyers handling the case. Raissi launched a [[civil suit]] against the ''[[Mail on Sunday]]'' for printing false information about criminal charges he faced, and citing the fact that airlines will not hire him because of the accusations against him. He was awarded an undisclosed sum. On February 22, 2007, Mr Raissi lost his case in the UK High Court to claim compensation for wrongful arrest and the 5 months he spent in Belmarsh. Judges ruled him ineligible on the grounds that he had been held as part of an extradition case rather than 'in the domestic criminal process'. He took his case to the Court of Appeal and the High Court ruling was overturned, Appeal Judges stating that evidence showed the CPS and the Police were responsible for "serious defaults". Raissi's case remains a contentious issue in Algeria, whose government refuses to sign an agreement with Britain about [[extradition|extraditing]] hijackers until Britain acknowledges that its treatment of Raissi was flawed. British authorities continue to insist that British police and prosecutors acted properly, and it was American authorities who were at fault for supplying them with bad intelligence. In February 2008 the Court of Appeal rejected this position, 'completely exonerated' Raissi, and ordered British authorities to reconsider his entitlement to compensation, which had previously been rejected. It also found that the Crown Prosecution Service and the police had presented false evidence to the courts. {{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article3368163.ece |title=Judges condemn police lies after 9/11 attacks that ruined pilot's life |publisher=[[The Times]] |author=[[Sean O'Neill (journalist)|Sean O'Neill]] |date=2008-02-15 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |quote= |location=London |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fbusiness.timesonline.co.uk%2Ftol%2Fbusiness%2Flaw%2Farticle3368163.ece&date=2008-08-12 |archivedate=2008-08-12 |df= }} His application for permission to enforce the order of the Court of Appeal, and contempt of court proceedings against the Home Office, resulted in an announcement on 23 April 2010 by the [[Secretary of State for Justice]] [[Jack Straw]] that Raissi is eligible for up to £2m compensation.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/23/airline-pilot-cleared-9-11-lotfi-raissi | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Airline pilot cleared of role in 9/11 after 'nine years of hell' | first=Karen | last=McVeigh | date=2010-04-23 | accessdate=2010-05-11}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== *[http://news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/terrorism/usraissi100901ind.pdf findlaw.com], FindLaw.com pdf of grand jury charges of false identity *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1361133/My-son-was-brought-up-to-abhor-terrorists.html My son was brought up to abhor terrorists], ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph Online]]'', November 1, 2001 *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-1797955,00.html Police blunder after 9/11 'destroyed pilot's career'], ''[[The Times|Times Online]]'', September 26, 2005 *[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/nov/22/lotfi-raissi-algerian-pilot-case Lotfi Raissi case: How false link to al-Qaida kept innocent Algerian in jail] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 22 November 2009 {{9-11 hijackers}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Raissi, Lotfi}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bab El Oued]] [[Category:People from Berkshire]] [[Category:People associated with the September 11 attacks]] [[Category:Commercial aviators]]

revision.comment: /* Legacy */
revision.text:
{{redirect|SS St. Louis||List of ships named SS St. Louis}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:StLouisHavana.jpg|300px|SS ''St. Louis'' surrounded by smaller vessels in its home port of Hamburg]] |Ship caption=MS ''St. Louis'' surrounded by smaller vessels in its homeport of [[Hamburg]].<ref>[http://digitalassets.ushmm.org/photoarchives/detail.aspx?id=18122 Photo Archives United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]</ref> }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship name=''St. Louis'' |Ship country=[[Germany]] |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Nazi Germany|civil}} {{shipboxflag|West Germany|civil}} |Ship owner =[[Hamburg-America Line]] |Ship registry=*{{flagicon|Weimar Republic|civil}} [[Hamburg]] (1928–33) *{{flagicon|Nazi Germany}} Hamburg (1933–46) *{{flagicon|Allied-occupied Germany}} Hamburg (1946–49) *{{flagicon|West Germany}} Hamburg (1949–52) |Ship builder = [[Bremer-Vulkan Shipyards]] in [[Bremen (city)|Bremen]], Germany |Ship laid down = June 16, 1925 |Ship launched = August 2, 1928 |Ship maiden voyage = March 28, 1929 |Ship fate = Scrapped in [[Bremerhaven]], Germany, 1952 }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type= Cruiser |Ship tonnage = {{GRT|16,732|disp=long}} |Ship length = {{convert|574|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam = {{convert|72|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship ramps= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=M.A.N. diesels, twin triple-blade propellers |Ship speed = 16 knots (30 km/h/18 mph) |Ship range= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity = 937 passengers (270 cabin, 287 tourist, 416 third)}} |} '''MS ''St. Louis''''' was a German [[ocean liner]]. In 1939, she set off on a voyage in which her captain, [[Gustav Schröder]], tried to find homes for over 900 Jewish refugees from Germany. They were denied entry to [[Cuba]], the [[United States]], and [[Canada]]. The refugees were finally accepted in various European countries, including Belgium, the Netherlands, the UK, and France. Historians have estimated that approximately a quarter of them died in [[Extermination camp|death camps]] during World War II.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://activehistory.ca/?s=Netherlands+&submit=Search|title=Remembering the Voyage of the St. Louis|last=Madokoro|first=Laura|date=|website=Active History |access-date=}}</ref> The passengers' experience has been treated in film, opera, and fiction.
==Background== Built by the [[Bremer Vulkan]] shipyards in [[Bremen (city)|Bremen]] for ''HAPAG'', better known in English as the [[Hamburg America Line]], ''St. Louis'' was a [[diesel engine|diesel]]-powered ship (as opposed to a diesel-fired [[Steamship|steamer]]) and properly referred to with the prefix [[Motor ship|MS]] or MV, but she is often known as SS ''St. Louis''. The ship was named after the city of [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. (Her sistership, the ''[[MS Milwaukee]]'', was also a diesel motor ship/motor vessel owned by the Hamburg America Line). ''St. Louis'' regularly sailed the [[Transatlantic crossing|trans-Atlantic route]] from [[Hamburg]] to [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]] and New York and made cruises to the Canary Islands, Madeira and Morocco. ''St. Louis'' was built for both transatlantic liner service and for [[Cruise ship|leisure cruises]].{{cn|date=September 2014}}
=="Voyage of the Damned"== ''St. Louis'' set sail from Hamburg to Cuba on May 13, 1939. The vessel under command of Captain [[Gustav Schröder]] was carrying 937 passengers, most of them Jewish refugees<ref name="ushmm">{{cite press release|title=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum completes ten-year search to uncover the fates of St. Louis passengers|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|date=October 6, 2006|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/press/archives/detail.php?category=07-general&content=2006-10-06|accessdate =July 17, 2007 |archivedate=June 26, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626063439/http://www.ushmm.org/museum/press/archives/detail.php?category=07-general&content=2006-10-06}}</ref><ref name=Rosen-563>Rosen, p. 563.</ref> seeking asylum from Nazi ill-treatment of Jews in Germany (→ [[Kristallnacht]], [[Racial policy of Nazi Germany]]). Captain Schröder was a non-Jewish German<ref name="yadvashem">{{cite web |url=http://db.yadvashem.org/righteous/family.html?language=en&itemId=4017400 |title=The Righteous Among The Nations: Gustav Schroeder |website=Yad Vashem |accessdate=Jan 29, 2017 }}</ref> who went to great lengths to ensure dignified treatment for his passengers.
The passengers aboard ''St. Louis'' had suffered abuse in Germany, but on board, they were treated very well, at the insistence of Captain Schröder.<ref>Levine, p. 105.</ref> Food served included items subject to rationing in Germany, and childcare was available while parents dined. Dances and concerts were put on, and on Friday evenings, religious services were held in the dining room. A bust of Hitler was covered by a tablecloth. Swimming lessons took place in the on-deck pool. Lothar Molton, a boy traveling with his parents, said that the passengers thought of it as "a vacation cruise to freedom".<ref>Levine, pp. 110–11.</ref>
The ship dropped anchor at 04:00 on May 27 at the far end of the [[Havana Harbor]] but was denied entry to the usual docking areas. The Cuban government, headed by President [[Federico Laredo Brú]], refused to accept the foreign refugees. Although passengers had previously purchased legal visas, they could not enter Cuba either as tourists (laws related to tourist visas had recently been changed) or as refugees seeking political asylum. On May 5, 1939, four months before World War II began, Havana abandoned its former pragmatic immigration policy and instead issued Decree 937, which "restricted entry of all foreigners except U.S. citizens requiring a bond of $500 and authorization by the Cuban secretaries of state and labor. Permits and visas issued before May 5 were invalidated retroactively.<ref>Levine, p. 103</ref> None of the passengers were aware that the Cuban government had retroactively invalidated their landing permits.
After five days in the harbor, only 29 passengers were allowed to disembark in Cuba.<ref>Levine, p. 114.</ref><ref name="rosen-speech"/> Twenty-two of them were Jews that had valid US visas; of the others, four were Spanish citizens and two were Cuban nationals, all with valid entry documents. The last was a medical evacuee who, after attempting to commit suicide, was taken to a hospital in Havana.<ref name="ushmm"/>{{failed verification|date=November 2017}} [[File:StLouisHamburg.jpg|thumb|left|Boarding at [[Port of Hamburg|Hamburg Harbor]]]] Telephone records show American officials [[Cordell Hull]], Secretary of State, and [[Henry Morgenthau, Jr.|Henry Morgenthau]], [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]] had made some efforts to persuade Cuba to accept the refugees. Their actions, together with efforts of the [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee]], were not successful.<ref name="rosen-speech"/>
Prohibited from landing in Cuba, ''St. Louis'' and the remaining 907 refugees<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archives.jdc.org/assets/documents/thevoyageofthest-louis.pdf |title=The Voyage of the ''St. Louis'' |date=June 15, 1939 |accessdate=Jan 29, 2017 |website=American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee }}</ref> headed towards the United States. Captain Schröder circled off the coast of Florida, hoping for permission to enter the United States. [[Cordell Hull]], Secretary of State, advised Roosevelt not to accept the Jews, however. Captain Schröder considered running aground along the coast to allow the refugees to escape, but, acting on Cordell Hull's instructions, [[US Coast Guard]] vessels shadowed the ship and prevented such a move.
After ''St. Louis'' was turned away from the United States,<ref name="USCG">{{cite web |url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/faqs/St_Louis.asp |title=What was the Coast Guard's role in the SS St. Louis affair, often referred to as "The Voyage of the Damned"? |website=United States Coast Guard History |date=Dec 21, 2016 |accessdate=Jan 29, 2017 }}</ref> a group of academics and clergy in Canada tried to persuade Canada's Prime Minister, [[William Lyon Mackenzie King]], to provide sanctuary to the ship's passengers, as it was only two days from [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]].<ref>[http://www.gov.ns.ca/news/details.asp?id=20091105005 "Maritime Museum Exhibit on Tragic Voyage of MS St. Louis", November 5, 2010, Nova Scotia Government Press Release]; accessed September 12, 2014.</ref> But Canadian immigration official [[Frederick Blair]], hostile to Jewish immigration, persuaded the prime minister on June 9 not to intervene. In 2000, Blair's nephew apologized to the Jewish people for his uncle's action.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canadian-clergy-apologize-to-voyage-of-the-damned-survivors-1.227709 "Clergy apologize for turning away the ''St. Louis''"], CBC website; retrieved 2008-05-08.</ref>
The situation of the vessel deteriorated as Captain Schröder negotiated and schemed to find them a safe haven. At one point he formulated plans to wreck the ship on the British coast to force the passengers to be taken as refugees. He refused to return the ship to Germany until all the passengers had been given entry to some other country. US officials worked with Britain and European nations to find refuge for the travelers in Europe.<ref name="rosen-speech"/> The ship returned to Europe, docking at the [[Port of Antwerp]] (Belgium) on June 17, 1939, with 907 passengers.<ref>George Axelsson, "907 Refugees End Voyage in Antwerp", ''New York Times,'' June 18, 1939</ref><ref>Levine, p. 118.</ref>
British Prime Minister [[Neville Chamberlain]] agreed to take 288 (32%) of the passengers, who disembarked and traveled to the UK via other steamers. After much negotiation by Schröder, the remaining 619 passengers were allowed to disembark at [[Antwerp]]; 224 (25%) were accepted by France, 214 (23.59%) by [[Belgium]], and 181 (20%) by the [[Netherlands]]. The ship returned to Hamburg without any passengers. The following year, after the [[Battle of France|Nazi German invasions of Belgium, France and the Netherlands]] in May 1940, all the Jews in those countries were at renewed risk, including the recent refugees.<ref>Rosen, pp. 103, 567.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/stlouis.html|title=The Tragedy of the S.S. St. Louis|accessdate=July 17, 2007}}</ref> [[File:GSchroederAntwerp.jpg|thumb|left|''St. Louis'' Captain Gustav Schröder negotiates landing permits for the passengers with [[Belgium|Belgian]] officials in the [[Port of Antwerp]].]] Based on the survival rates for Jews in various countries, historians estimate that 180 of ''St. Louis'' refugees in France, 152 of those in Belgium, and 60 of those in the Netherlands survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref>{{cite book| title= Voyage of the Damned | author = Thomas and Morgan-Witts}}</ref> Including the passengers who landed in England, of the original 936 refugees (one man died during the voyage), roughly 709 survived the war and 227 did not.<ref>Rosen, pp. 447, 567 citing Morgan-Witts and Thomas (1994) pp. 8, 238</ref><ref name="rosen-speech">{{cite speech|title=Saving the Jews|first=Robert|last=Rosen|date=July 17, 2006|location=[[Carter Center]] (Atlanta, Georgia)|url=http://www.savingthejews.com/html/carterlibraryspeech.htm|accessdate=July 17, 2007}}</ref>
More detailed research tracing each passenger has determined that 254 of those who returned to continental Europe were murdered during the Holocaust: {{blockquote|Of the 620 ''St. Louis'' passengers who returned to continental Europe, we determined that eighty-seven were able to emigrate before Germany invaded western Europe on May 10, 1940. Two hundred fifty-four passengers in Belgium, France, and the Netherlands after that date died during the Holocaust. Most of these people were murdered in the killing centers of [[Auschwitz]] and [[Sobibor extermination camp|Sobibór]]; the rest died in internment camps, in hiding or attempting to evade the Nazis. Three hundred sixty-five of the 620 passengers who returned to continental Europe survived the war. Of the 288 passengers sent to Britain, the vast majority were alive at war's end.<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=szsEtvPJ--cC&pg=PA174& | author = Scott Miller and Sarah Ogilvie |pages= 174–75 |date= 2010 | publisher = University of Wisconsin Press | title = Refuge Denied: The St. Louis Passengers and the Holocaust}}</ref>}}
==Legacy== After the war, Captain Gustav Schröder was awarded the [[Bundesverdienstkreuz|Order of Merit by the Federal Republic of Germany]]. In 1993, Schröder was posthumously named as one of the [[Righteous among the Nations]] at the [[Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial]] in Israel.<ref name="yadvashem"/> A display at the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] tells the story of the voyage of the MS ''St. Louis''. The [[Hamburg Museum]] features a display and a video about ''St. Louis'' in its exhibits about the history of shipping in the city. In 2009, a special exhibit at the [[Maritime Museum of the Atlantic]] in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia]] entitled "Ship of Fate" explored the Canadian connection to the tragic voyage. The display is now a traveling exhibit in Canada.<ref>[https://maritimemuseum.novascotia.ca/what-see-do/travelling-exhibit-ms-st-louis-ship-fate "Traveling Exhibit MS ''St. Louis'' Ship of Fate", ''Maritime Museum of the Atlantic'']</ref>
In 2011 a memorial monument called the ''Wheel of Conscience'', was produced by the [[Canadian Jewish Congress]], designed by [[Daniel Libeskind]] with graphic design by [[David Berman (graphic designer)|David Berman]] and Trevor Johnston.<ref>[http://www.daniel-libeskind.com/news/news-single-view/article/353/cjc-and-pier ''Studio Daniel Libeskind''], daniel-libeskind.com, 19 January 2011; retrieved 21 January 2011.</ref> The memorial is a polished [[stainless steel]] wheel. Symbolizing the policies that turned away more than 900 Jewish refugees, the wheel incorporates four inter-meshing [[gears]] each showing a word to represent factors of exclusion: [[antisemitism]], [[xenophobia]], [[racism]], and [[hatred]]. The back of the memorial is inscribed with the passenger list.<ref>{{cite web |last=Taplin |first=Jennifer |title=Perpetual Memorial of Regret |publisher=Metro News Halifax |date=21 January 2011 |url=http://www.metronews.ca/news/halifax/2011/01/21/perpetual-memorial-of-regret.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310142419/http://www.metronews.ca/news/halifax/2011/01/21/perpetual-memorial-of-regret.html |archivedate=10 March 2016 |accessdate=22 March 2017 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> It was first exhibited in 2011 at the [[Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21]], Canada's national immigration museum in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]]. After a display period, the sculpture was shipped to its fabricators, Soheil Mosun Limited, in Toronto for repair and refurbishment.<ref>[http://www.pier21.ca/exhibitions "Exhibitions", Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21''], pier21.ca; accessed 12 September 2014.</ref>
In 2012, the [[United States Department of State]] apologized in a ceremony attended by Deputy Secretary [[William Joseph Burns|Bill Burns]] and 14 survivors of the incident.<ref name="State Department">{{cite web|last1=Eppinger|first1=Kamerel|title=State Department apologizes to Jewish refugees|url=http://www.shfwire.com/state-department-apologizes-jewish-refugees/|website=shfwire.com|accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref> The survivors presented a proclamation of gratitude to various European countries for accepting some of the ship’s passengers. A signed copy of Senate Resolution 111, recognizing June 6, 2009 as the 70th anniversary of the incident, was delivered to the Department of State Archives.<ref name="State Department" />
In January 2017, software engineer Russel Neiss and Rabbi Charlie Schwartz set up a [https://twitter.com/Stl_Manifest Twitter account] which tweeted the name of each passenger who was not allowed to disembark and subsequently killed. The format of each tweet included the passenger's name, the sentence "The US turned me away at the border in 1939" and the location where each was killed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Daley|first1=Jason|title=Haunting Twitter Account Shares the Fates of the Refugees of the St. Louis|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/haunting-twitter-account-shares-the-fates-of-the-refugees-of-st-louis-180961955/|website=smithsonianmag.com|accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref>
In May 2018, [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Justin Trudeau]] announced the Government of Canada would offer a formal apology in the country's [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] for its role in the fate of the ship's passengers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/trudeau-apology-st-louis-1.4654516 |title=Trudeau to offer formal apology in Commons for fate of Jewish refugee ship MS St. Louis |accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> The apology was issued on November 7.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/trudeau-apologizes-canadas-1939-refusal-jewish-refugee-ship-214025605.html|title=Trudeau apologizes for Canada's 1939 refusal of Jewish refugee ship|accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
==Later career== The MS ''St. Louis'' was adapted as a German naval accommodation ship from 1940 to 1944. She was heavily damaged by the Allied bombings at [[Kiel]] on August 30, 1944, but was repaired and used as a hotel ship in Hamburg in 1946. She was later sold and was [[scrapped]] in 1952.{{cn|date=September 2014}}
==Notable passengers== *Leon Joel, great-uncle of American singer-songwriter [[Billy Joel]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Billy Joel über die Enteignung seiner jüdischen Familie, Bühnentriumphe und gescheiterte Ehen|url=https://www.stern.de/kultur/musik/billy-joel-ueber-die-enteignung-seiner-familie-durch-josef-neckermann-8002688.html|website=stern.de|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref> * [[Arno Motulsky]] (1923-2018), genome scientist<ref>[http://depts.washington.edu/medgen/documents/ArnosWarStory.pdf Holding out hope in a cruel world] publ.: [[University of Washington]]</ref>
==Representations== {{unref|section|date=May 2018}} * ''[[Voyage of the Damned]]'' (1974) by [[Gordon Thomas (author)|Gordon Thomas]] and [[Max Morgan-Witts]] * ''St. Louis Blues'' (1994), an opera by [[Chiel Meijering]] * ''[[Voyage of the Damned]]'' (1976), a film directed by [[Stuart Rosenberg]] * [[Julian Barnes]]'s novel ''[[A History of the World in 10½ Chapters]]'' (1989) recounts the trials of the MS ''St. Louis'' Jews in the chapter "Three Simple Stories" * [[Bodie and Brock Thoene]]'s 1991 novel ''Munich Signature'' * [[Leonardo Padura]]'s novel ''[[Herejes]]'' (Tusquets, 2013) centers around the St. Louis incident. * [[Jan de Hartog]]'s play "Schipper naast God" (1942), translated as "Skipper next to God" (1945) * [[Nilo Cruz]]' play "Sotto Voce" (2014), dealing with modern remnants of the ship's tragedy. * ''[[The German Girl]]'' (2016), a novel by [[Armando Lucas Correa]] * ''Refugee'' (2017), a young adult novel by [[Alan Gratz]] * ''Denied Entry: A Survivor's Story of Fate, Faith, and Freedom'' (2011), an autobiography and commentary by [[Philip S. Freund]]
==See also== * [[Patria disaster|SS ''Patria'']], sunk by a [[Haganah]] bomb on 25 November 1940 in the [[Port of Haifa]]. * {{SS|Navemar}}, designed for 28 passengers, in 1941 the vessel carried 1,120 Jewish refugees to New York. * [[Struma disaster|MV ''Struma'']], a schooner chartered to carry Jewish refugees that was torpedoed and sunk by a Soviet submarine on 5 February 1942. * {{MV|Mefküre}}, a schooner carrying Jewish refugees that was torpedoed and sunk by a Soviet submarine on 5 August 1944. * ''[[Komagata Maru incident|Komagata Maru]]'', a merchant ship carrying Asian migrants that was denied entry to Canada in 1914.
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
;Sources *{{cite book |first=Robert M. |last=Levine |title=Tropical Diaspora: The Jewish Experience in Cuba |place=Gainesville |publisher=University Press of Florida |date=1993 |page=103 |isbn=9781558765214 }} *{{cite book | last = Miller | first = Scott |author2=Sarah A. Ogilvie | title = Refuge Denied: The St. Louis Passengers and the Holocaust | publisher = University of Wisconsin Press | location = Madison | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-0-299-21980-2 | oclc = 64592065}} *{{cite book | last = Rosen | first = Robert | title = Saving the Jews: Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Holocaust | publisher = Thunder's Mouth Press | location = New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-1-56025-778-3 | oclc = 64664326 }} *{{cite book | last = Whitaker | first = Reginald | title = Canadian Immigration Policy | publisher = Canadian Historical Association | location = Ottawa | year = 1991 | isbn = 0-88798-120-8}} {{Refend}}
==Further reading== * Levinson, Jay. ''Jewish Community of Cuba: Golden Years, 1906–1958'', Nashville, TN: Westview Publishing, 2005. (See Chapter 10) *{{cite book | last = Morgan-Witts | first = Max | authorlink = Max Morgan-Witts |author2=Gordon Thomas |authorlink2=Gordon Thomas (author) | title = Voyage of the Damned | publisher = Motorbooks International | location = Stillwater, Minnesota | year = 1994 | edition = 2nd, revised (first in 1974)| isbn = 978-0-87938-909-3 | oclc = 31373409 }} * Ogilvie, Sarah; Scott Miller. ''Refuge Denied: The St. Louis Passengers and the Holocaust'', Madison, WI: University of Wisconsin Press, 2006. * Sampson, Pamela. ''No Reply: A Jewish Child Aboard the MS St. Louis and the Ordeal That Followed'', Atlanta, GA, 2017 * Lawlor, A. ''The Saddest Ship Afloat: The Tragedy of the MS St. Louis,'' Nimbus Publishing, ''2016.'' {{ISBN|978-1771083997}} * [[Irving Abella]] and [[Harold Troper]]'s ''[[None Is Too Many: Canada and the Jews of Europe 1933-1948]]''
==External links== {{commons category|SS St. Louis}} {{Library resources box}} *[http://www.savingthejews.com/html/carterlibraryspeech.htm Robert Rosen, "Carter Center Library Speech" on "The S.S. St. Louis"], July 17, 2006, ''Saving the Jews: Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Holocaust'' *[http://www.uscg.mil/history/faqs/St_Louis.asp "The St. Louis"], US Coast Guard's official FAQ *[http://www.ushmm.org/information/exhibitions/online-features/special-focus/american-responses-to-the-holocaust/st-louis "American Responses to the Holocaust - St. Louis"], U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum * [http://archives.jdc.org/educators/topic-guides/the-story-of-the-ss-st.html "The Story of the S.S. St. Louis (1939)"] American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee Archives * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-27373131 "SS St Louis: The ship of Jewish refugees nobody wanted"] BBC News
{{Latin America during World War II}}

revision.text:
A '''pamper party''', or '''pampering party''', is a female-oriented party in which the guests receives beauty and massage treatments and generally spend time to indulge and pamper themselves.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is a Pamper Party?|url=http://www.pamperparties.com/pamper_parties/pamper_party.php|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref>
Pamper parties are usually held in the hostess's home, but they are sometimes offered by spas and salons. In the [[UK]], a pamper party is a popular component of a hen party or hen weekend, which would be termed a [[bachelorette party]] in the [[US]],
Pamper parties are usually considered to be a healthy indulgence; in addition to pampering treatments, the hostess usually provides healthy snacks, fruit juices and smoothies.{{needs citation|date=October 2014}}
==Children's pamper parties==
Pamper parties may also be organized as a variation to a girl's birthday party for slightly older children in which the theme of the event seeks to mimic an adult pamper party in a safe environment, such as a parent's home. They combine elements of children's parties, such as party-bags, with elements of adult pamper parties, such as cosmetics and well-being, in a child-friendly manner with "pamper baskets" typically being given to younger guests.<ref>{{cite web|title=Example of children's pamper basket|url=http://www.partybagkids.co.uk/pamper-party-little-princess-perfect-pamper-party-take-home-gift/|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> It is common for the events to be combined with a [[sleepover]], slumber party or pajama party. Similarly, it is a form is "[[rite of passage]]" from childhood to adulthood.
==See also== *[[Hen Party]]
==References== {{reflist}}[http://www.belvederepamperco.co.uk Pamper parties, & Home spa]{{Parties}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pamper Party}} [[Category:Parties]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = Paris Air Show | native_name = Salon international de l'aéronautique et de l'espace, Paris-Le Bourget | image = Paris Air Show 2007 01.jpg | caption = The first day of the 2007 Paris Air Show | status = Active | genre = Commercial [[air show]] | dates = June | frequency = Odd years | venue = [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport]] | location = [[Le Bourget]], Paris (since 1953) | coordinates = {{Coord|48.9555|2.4324|type:landmark_source:enwiki-googlemaplink|display=inline,title}} | country = France | established = {{start date and age|1909}} | attendance = 2017: {{#expr:142000+180000}} | activity = Aerobatic displays
Static displays | organized = SIAE ([[GIFAS]]) | website = [http://www.paris-air-show.com/ paris-air-show.com] }} The '''Paris Air Show''' ('''''Salon international de l'aéronautique et de l'espace de Paris-Le Bourget, Salon du Bourget''''') is the largest [[Air Show]] before UK's [[Farnborough Air Show|Farnborough]], followed by [[Dubai Air Show]] or [[Singapore Airshow]].{{cite news |url= https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/aerospace/2017-11-08/2017-dubai-airshow-expected-be-largest-yet |title= 2017 Dubai Airshow Expected To Be Largest Yet |author= Peter Shaw-Smith |date= November 8, 2017 |work= AIN}} The latest was the 52nd Air Show, held from 19 to 25 June 2017, attended by 3,450 journalists, 142,000 professionals and 180,000 general public visitors. It claims to be the world's calendar-oldest [[air show]].{{cite web | author=Bill Carey | publisher=AIN Online |url=http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/paris-air-show/2013-06-17/us-military-no-show-2013-paris-air-show |title=U.S. Military a No-show At 2013 Paris Air Show |access-date=2013-09-07}} Established in 1909 as the [[ILA Berlin Air Show]], it has been held every odd year since 1949 at [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport]] in north Paris, France. It is a large [[trade fair]], demonstrating military and civilian aircraft, and is attended by many [[military force]]s and the major [[aircraft manufacturer]]s, often announcing major aircraft sales. It starts with four professional days and is then opened to the general public followed from Friday to Sunday. The format is similar to Farnborough and the ILA, both staged in even years. It is organised by the French aerospace industry's primary representative body, the ''Groupement des industries françaises aéronautiques et spatiales'' ([[GIFAS]]). == History == [[File:Salon de locomotion aerienne 1909 Grand Palais Paris.jpg|thumb|The first ''Salon de la locomotion aérienne'', 1909, [[Grand Palais]], Paris.]] The Paris Air Show traces its history back to the first decade of the 20th century. In 1908 a section of the [[Paris Motor Show]] was dedicated to aircraft.[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200004.html "The First Paris Aeronautical Salon"] ''Flight'' January 2, 1909. The following year, a dedicated air show was held at the [[Grand Palais]][http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200603.html "Paris Flight Show -First Impressions of an Artistic and Fascinating Display"] ''Flight'' October 2, 1909 from 25 September to 17 October, during which 100,000 visitors turned out to see products and innovations from 380 exhibitors.{{cite web|title=Show History|publisher=Paris-air-show.com|url=http://www.paris-air-show.com/en/the-show/show-history|access-date=20 March 2011}} There were four further shows before the [[World War I|First World War]].{{cite web|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200990.html |title=special paris | salon | side entrance | 1912 | 0990 | Flight Archive |publisher=Flightglobal.com |date= |access-date=2012-10-15}} {{Citation needed span|The show restarted in 1919, and from 1924 it was held every two years before being interrupted again by the [[World War II|Second World War]]. It restarted in 1946 and since 1949, has been held in every odd year.|date=July 2016}} [[File:Sud SE-212 Durandal Le Bourget 1957.jpg|thumb|[[SNCASE SE.212 Durandal]] experimental jet/rocket fighter aircraft at the 1957 Air Salon]] The air show continued to be held at the Grand Palais, and from 1949 flying demonstrations were staged at Paris [[Orly Airport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.entrevoisins.org/aeroport/bourget/Le-Salon-du-Bourget-histoire.aspx|title=Le Salon du Bourget, témoin de l'histoire de l'aéronautique et de l'espace - Entrevoisins.org|first=Agence Minit-L,|last=www.minit-l.net|date=|website=www.entrevoisins.org|accessdate=4 April 2018}} In 1953, the show was relocated from the Grand Palais to Le Bourget.{{cite web|url=http://www.parisaeroport.fr/groupe/groupe-et-strategie/histoire/1945_a_1960|title=1945 à 1960|author=|date=|website=www.parisaeroport.fr|accessdate=4 April 2018}} The show was drawing international notice in the 1960s.{{cite news |agency=UPI |title=De Gaulle Opens Air Show in Paris |work=New York Times |date=May 27, 1967 |location=New York, New York |page=15 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1967/05/27/90345490.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=15 |accessdate = September 19, 2018}} Since the 1970s, the show has emerged as the main international reference of the aeronautical sector.{{cite web|url=http://www.promosalons.com/salon-du-bourget.html|title=Salon du Bourget - Salon international de l’aéronautique et de l’espace|author=|date=|website=www.promosalons.com|accessdate=4 April 2018}} ===1967=== The 1967 air show was opened by French President [[Charles de Gaulle]], who toured the exhibits and shook hands with two Soviet [[astronaut|cosmonauts]] and two American [[astronauts]]. Prominently displayed by the [[Soviet Union]] was a three-stage [[Vostok (rocket family)|Vostok rocket]], such as the one that had carried [[Yuri Gagarin]] into space on April 12, 1961. The "extraordinarily powerful" Vostok was downplayed by American missile experts as "rather old and unsophisticated."Mooney, Richard E. "Soviet Competes with U.S. in Paris." ''New York Times''. May 26. 1967. 92.. The American exhibit, the largest at the fair, featured the [[F-111]] swing-wing fighter bomber, a replica of [[Charles Lindberg|Charles Lindbergh's]] ''[[Spirit of St. Louis]]''.{{cite news |title=Replica of Famous Plane Sent to Paris |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23872935/spirit_of_st_louis/ |work=Los Angeles Times |date=May 15, 1967 |location=California, Los Angeles |page=24|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 19, 2018}} {{Open access}} and the [[LTV XC-142A|Ling-Temco-Vought XC-142A]], a cargo plane capable of a vertical takeoff and landing.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Jack |title=Base Pilot Taking F-111 to Paris |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23877954/us_exhibits_in_paris |work=Dayton Daily News |date=May 14, 1967 |location=Ohio, Dayton |page=56|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 19, 2018}} {{Open access}} A full-size model of the supersonic [[Concorde]] was displayed by the French and British, auguring its successful first flight on March 2, 1969.Witkin, Richard. "Supersonic Concorde Airliner Successful in 28-Minute Maiden Flight." ''New York Times''. March 3, 1969. 1. ===1969=== "The largest plane in the world," the [[Boeing 747]] jet airliner, arrived on June 3, after flying non-stop from [[Seattle]], Washington,{{cite news |title=Boeing 747 Jumbo Jetliner Flown to Paris Air Show |work=New York Times |date=June 4, 1969 |location=New York, New York |page=94}} and the [[Apollo 8]] command module, charred by its re-entry, was there flanked by the [[Apollo 9]] astronauts, but the most-viewed exhibit was the supersonic [[Concorde]], which made its first flight over Paris as the show opened.{{cite news |title=Concorde Flies Over Paris |work=New York Times |date=May 30, 1969 |location=New York, New York |page=40}} ===1971=== The Soviet [[TU-144]] supersonic airliner was flown to [[Le Bourget]] for the 1971 show,{{cite news |title=Soviet SST, in Its First Flight to the West, Arrives in Paris for Air Show |work = New York Times |date=May 26, 1971 |location=New York, New York |page=3 }}{{cite news |title=Soviet SST Arrives for Paris Air Show |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23990026/tu_144_arrives_in_paris/ |work=Los Angeles Times |date=May 26, 1971 |location=California, Los Angeles |page=6|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 23, 2018}} {{Open access}} drawing comparisons with the French [[Concorde]].{{cite news |title='74 Service Due for Both Soviet and Concorde |work = New York Times |date=May 29, 1971 |location=New York, New York |page=46 }}{{cite news |last=Angove |first=Rodney |title=Soviet. British-French SST Compared |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23990641/sst_comparison/ |work=Tampa Tribune |date=May 27, 1971 |location=Florida, Tampa |page=73|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 23, 2018}} {{Open access}} Landing with the Concorde was the world's largest aircraft, the American [[Lockheed C-5 Galaxy|Lockheed C-5A Galaxy]].{{cite news |agency=UPI |title=World's Biggest Aircraft Now At Paris Show |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23995379/c5a_galaxy/ |work=Times Record |date=May 26, 1971 |location=New York, Troy |page=2|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 23, 2018}} {{Open access}} ===1973=== The [[1973 Paris Air Show Tu-144 crash|crash of the Soviet Tu-144]], see below, overshadowed the 1973 show, otherwise characterized by "There was nothing new", although the flying was memorable,{{cite journal |last1=Field |first1=Hugh |title=Paris Show Review |journal=Flight International |date=June 7, 1973 |pages=865-67 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1973/1973%20-%201561.html |accessdate=September 25, 2018}} and there were a great many exhibits.{{cite journal |title=Other Countries |journal=Flight International |date=May 24, 1973 |pages=805-09 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1973/1973%20-%201425.html |accessdate=September 25, 2018}} ===1975=== One hundred and eighty-two aircraft were scheduled for appearance.{{cite journal |title=Au Bourget… The aircraft on show |journal=Flight International |date=May 29, 1975 |volume=107 |issue=3455 |page=862 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1975/1975%20-%200958.html?search=862 |accessdate=September 26, 2018}} Despite restrictions that followed the [[1973 Paris Air Show Tu-144 crash|TU-144 crash in 1973]], a day of flying pleased viewers. In particular, the American [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|YF-16]] and the French [[Dassault Mirage F1|Mirage F-1E]] competed in turn before a critical audience.{{cite journal |title=Apres Le Bourget |journal=Flight International |date=June 12, 1975 |volume=107 |issue=3457 |pages=931-32 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1975/1975%20-%201031.html |accessdate=September 26, 2018}} Days later, Belgium became the fourth European nation to choose the YF-16 over the F-1E.{{cite journal |title=Apres Le Bourget… F-16 carries it off |journal=Flight International |date=June 12, 1975 |volume=107 |issue=3457 |page=934 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1975/1975%20-%201034.html |accessdate=September 25, 2018}} ===1977=== Celebration of [[Charles Lindberg|Charles Lindbergh's]] trans-Atlantic flight to Le Bourget fifty years ago recalled that historic event.{{cite journal |title=1927-1977: Golden Lindbergh |journal=Flight International |date=June 4, 1977 |volume=111 |issue=3560 |pages=1650-53 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1977/1977%20-%201742.html |accessdate=September 27, 2018}} [[Anne Morrow Lindbergh]], Lindbergh's widow, attended the ceremony along with early trans-Atlantic pilots, [[Maurice Bellonte]] and Armand Lotti.{{cite news |title=Lone Eagle, Concorde and A-10 Dominate Air Show |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/06/05/archives/lone-eagle-concorde-and-a10-dominate-air-show.html |accessdate=September 27, 2018 |work=New York Times |date=June 5, 1977}} Recent extension of [[Exclusive economic zone|coastal limits]] to 200 nautical miles has produced new [[Maritime patrol aircraft|maritime-reconnaissance (MR) aircraft]].{{cite journal |title=Paris defenders |journal=Flight International |date=June 11, 1977 |volume=111 |issue=3561 |page=1687 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1977/1977%20-%201781.html |accessdate=September 27, 2018}} The crash of a [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|Fairchild A-10 tank-destroyer]] led to tightened rules on air show demonstrations.{{cite news |last1=Pullan |first1=Patricia |title=Lean budgets haunt air show |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/373217976/?terms=Fairchild%2BA-10# |accessdate=September 27, 2018 |work=Baltimore Sun |date=June 16, 1977}} ===1979=== Two airliners, the [[Airbus A310]] and the [[Boeing 767]], are competing for the international market, but neither will carry passengers before 1982.{{cite journal |last=Rek |first=Bron |title=Paris Special: A310 vs 767 |journal=Flight International |date=June 9, 1979 |volume=115 |issue=3664 |pages=2003-06, 11 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1979/1979%20-%202089.html |accessdate=September 28, 2018}} The [[Westland 30|Westland WG30]] transport helicopter shows promise.{{cite journal |last1=Lambert |first1=Mark |title=Paris Special: Westland WG30: first analysis |journal=Flight International |date=June 9, 1979 |volume=115 |issue=3664 |pages=2016-20 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1979/1979%20-%202102.html |accessdate=September 28, 2018}} "The [[Dassault Mirage 4000|Mirage 4000]] remains a question mark"{{cite journal |title=Mirage 4000: Dassault's independent delta |journal=Flight International |date=June 9, 1979 |volume=115 |issue=3664 |page=2077 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1979/1979%20-%202163.html |accessdate=September 28, 2018}} despite being "surely the main highlight this year at Le Bourget."{{cite journal |title=Paris Report: Defense |journal=Flight International |date=June 16, 1979 |volume=115 |issue=3665 |page=2152 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1979/1979%20-%202242.html |accessdate=September 28, 2018}} ===1981=== Exhibiting at the show, [[Airbus 320 family|Airbus]], [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing]], and [[McDonnell Douglas]]/[[Fokker]] vie for the 150-seat airline market, while [[Rolls Royce|Rolls Royce/Japan]], [[CFM International CFM56|General Electric/Snecma (CFM)]], and [[Pratt & Whitney]] contest for their engines.{{cite journal |last1=Learmount |first1=David |title=Is three a crowd? |journal=Flight International |date=June 13, 1981 |volume=119 |issue=3762 |page=1812 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1981/1981%20-%201893.html |accessdate=September 30, 2018}} The [[Northrop F-5|Northrop F-5G Tigershark]] mockup was on display and expected to fly in 1982 with delivery the following year. A novelty was Air Transat, a light aircraft trans-Atlantic race from [[Le Bourget]] to [[Sikorsky Memorial Airport]], [[Bridgeport]], Connecticut and back,{{cite journal |last1=Hutchinson |first1=Jeff |title=Transatlantic Air Race in view |journal=Flight International |date=May 30, 1981 |volume=119 |issue=3760 |page=1597 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1981/1981%20-%201603.html?search=%22Air%20Transat%20race%22 |accessdate=September 30, 2018}} won by a twin engine [[Piper PA-31 Navajo|Piper Navaho]]{{cite news |last1=Carman |first1=Gerry |title=Honor without price |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/121930897/?terms=Boyd%2BMunro# |accessdate=September 30, 2018 |work=The Age |location=Melbourne, Victoria, Australia |date=July 18, 1981 |page=24}} and a [[Beechcraft Bonanza]].{{cite journal |title=First Sheriff order announced |journal=Flight International |date=November 21, 1981 |volume=120 |issue=3785 |page=1546 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1981/1981%20-%203654.html?search=Transatlantic%20Air%20Race |accessdate=September 30, 2018}} ===1983=== The American [[Space Shuttle Enterprise|Space Shuttle ''Enterprise'']] was flown around Paris and towered over other exhibits,{{cite news |last1=Aplegren |first1=Janne |title=Space Place |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/122295656/?terms=Space%2Bshuttle%2BEnterprise# |accessdate=October 1, 2018 |work=The Age |location=Melbourne, Victoria, Australia |date=June 2, 1983}} but "much more intriguing"{{cite journal |title=Gemini |journal=Flight International |date=June 4, 1983 |volume=123 |issue=3865 |page=1617 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1983/1983%20-%200991.html |accessdate=October 1, 2018}} were replicas of two twin-engined fighters, the [[British Aerospace EAP|British Aerospace ACA]]{{cite journal |title=BAe gets ACA go-ahead |journal=Flight International |date=June 4, 1983 |volume=123 |issue=3865 |page=1621 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1983/1983%20-%200995.html?search=Dassault%20ACX |accessdate=October 1, 2018}} and French [[Dassault Rafale|Dassault Breguet ACX]].{{cite journal |title=Dassault unveils ACX |journal=Flight International |date=June 4, 1983 |volume=123 |issue=3865 |page=1621 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1983/1983%20-%200995.html?search=Dassault%20ACX |accessdate=October 1, 2018}} Sales of [[Boeing 757]] and [[Airbus A310]] airliners to [[Singapore Airlines]] were welcome news during an ongoing recession.{{cite journal |title=SIA peps order books |journal=Flight International |date=June 11, 1983 |volume=123 |issue=3866 |page=1734 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1983/1983%20-%201052.html |accessdate=October 1, 2018}} ===1985=== The Soviet [[Antonov An-124 Ruslan]] military heavy lifter was the largest exhibit in 1985.{{cite journal |title=Big man from Antonov |journal=Flight International |date=June 8, 1985 |volume=127 |issue=3963 |pages=3-4 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1985/1985%20-%201847.html |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} [[Propfan]] engines stirred interest.{{cite journal |title=Propfans ready by 1990 |journal=Flight International |date=June 8, 1985 |volume=127 |issue=3963 |page=5 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1985/1985%20-%201849.html |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} Reflecting the upturn in the economy, [[Boeing]] and [[Airbus]] announced new contracts totaling as much as $1,700 million.{{cite journal |title=Billion dollar airliner sales for leasing deals |journal=Flight International |date=June 8, 1985 |volume=127 |issue=3963 |page=13 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1985/1985%20-%201857.html |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} The [[Hubble space telescope]]{{cite news |last1=Anderson |first1=Ian |title=Giant eyes peer deep into space |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24225501/hubble_telescope_85/ |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |work=The Age |date=June 10, 1985 |location=Melbourne, Victoria |page=13}} should be deployed in 1986.{{cite journal |title=Space Telescope nears completion |journal=Flight International |date=June 8, 1985 |volume=127 |issue=3963 |page=39 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1985/1985%20-%201883.html |accessdate=October 2, 2018}} ===1987=== Newly introduced, in the rain, were the Soviet [[Mil Mi-34]] Helicopter,{{cite journal |title=Soviets unveil Mil Mi-34 |journal=Flight International |date=June 20, 1987 |volume=131 |issue=4067 |page=2 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%200976.html |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} the Israeli Super Phantom,{{cite journal |title=Super Phantom displayed |journal=Flight International |date=June 20, 1987 |volume=131 |issue=4067 |page=14 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%200988.html |accessdate=October 3, 2018}} and the Harrier GR.5.{{cite journal |last1=Gaines |first1=Mike |last2=Lowe |first2=Janice |title=Harrier force |journal=Flight International |date=July 18, 1987 |volume=132 |issue=4071 |pages=20-23 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%201214.html?search=Harrier |accessdate=October 3, 2018}} [[Airbus]] announced firm orders for both the [[A330]] and [[A340]] airliners.{{cite journal |title=Airbus Industrie reveals A330/A340 customers |journal=Flight International |date=June 20, 1987 |volume=131 |issue=4067 |page=11 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%200985.html |accessdate=October 3, 2018}} Exhibiting at the show for the first time, the Chinese displayed, among others, the [[Nanchang Q-5|A-5C Attacker (Fantan)]] and FT-7.{{cite journal |title=Chinese on show |journal=Flight International |date=June 20, 1987 |volume=131 |issue=4067 |page=12 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%200986.html |accessdate=October 3, 2018}} [[Dick Rutan|Richard Rutan]] and [[Jeana Yeager]], who flew a [[Rutan Voyager|Voyager]] non-stop around the world without refueling, were present, but their aircraft was not.{{cite journal |title=White House grounds Voyager |journal=Flight International |date=June 20, 1987 |volume=131 |issue=4067 |page=16 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%200990.html |accessdate=October 3, 2018}} === 1989 === [[File:Antonov An-225 with Buran at Le Bourget 1989 Manteufel.jpg|thumb| [[Antonov An-225 Mriya]] with [[Buran programme|Buran]] at Le Bourget, 1989]] The "38th Paris International Air and Space Show" or "1989 Paris Air Show", featured a variety of aerospace technology from [[NATO]] and [[Warsaw Pact]] nations.[http://www.dodmedia.osd.mil/DVIC_View/Still_Details.cfm?SDAN=DFST9007206&JPGPath=/Assets/1990/Air_Force/DF-ST-90-07206.JPG dodmedia id:DF-ST-90-07206] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614034910/http://www.dodmedia.osd.mil/DVIC_View/Still_Details.cfm?SDAN=DFST9007206&JPGPath=%2FAssets%2F1990%2FAir_Force%2FDF-ST-90-07206.JPG |date=2011-06-14 }} A [[Mikoyan MiG-29]] crashed during a demonstration flight with no loss of life. The then-Soviet space shuttle [[Buran (spacecraft)|Buran]] and its carrier, [[Antonov An-225 Mriya]], was displayed at this show. ===1991=== Despite a [[Department of Defense]] display of the [[Northrop Grumman B-2 Spirit|Stealth bomber]]{{cite journal |title=B-2's changing shape |journal=Flight International |date=June 12–18, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4271 |pages=101-02, 104 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201597.html |accessdate=October 5, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} and other [[Gulf War]] armaments,{{cite journal |title=Show guide |journal=Flight International |date=June 12–18, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4271 |page=50 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201546.html |accessdate=October 6, 2018}} most American contractors stayed home, so Soviet aircraft drew attention,{{cite journal |title=Empty gestures |journal=Flight International |date=June 19–25, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4272 |page=5 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201659.html |accessdate=October 6, 2018}} among them the [[Beriev A-40|Beriev Be-42 Mermaid (A-40 Albatros)]] amphibian,{{cite journal |title=Albatross by a head |journal=Flight International |date=April 17–23, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4263 |pages=36-38 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%200994.html |accessdate=October 6, 2018}} the [[Mikoyan MiG-31|MiG-31 Foxhound]] interceptor,{{cite journal |title=Foxhound breaks cover |journal=Flight International |date=June 12–18, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4271 |pages=87-88, 90-91 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201583.html?search=MiG-31 |accessdate=October 5, 2018}} and the [[Yakovlev Yak-141|Yak-141]] short take-off/vertical landing (ASTOVL) supersonic fighter.{{cite journal |title=Soviets reveal details of Yak-141 |journal=Flight International |date=June 19–25, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4272 |page=7 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201661.html |accessdate=October 5, 2018 }} When it receives its first customer order, Dassault plans to begin production of the [[Mirage 2000-5]], which is a "new machine compared to the basic [[Mirage 2000]]."{{cite journal |last1=Sedbon |first1=Gilbert |title=Dassault's high hope |journal=Flight International |date=June 12–18, 1991 |volume=139 |issue=4271 |pages=95-97 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1991/1991%20-%201591.html |accessdate=October 6, 2018}} === 1993 === The show attracted 1,611 exhibitors from 39 countries and nearly 300,000 visitors attended the show. [[Dassault Group|Dassault]] featured the debut of the [[Dassault Falcon 2000|Falcon 2000]],{{cite journal |last1=Moxon |first1=Julian |title=Economical Falcon |journal=Flight International |date=June 9–15, 1993 |volume=144 |issue=4373 |pages=60-64 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1993/1993%20-%201335.html |accessdate=October 10, 2018}} and [[Airbus]] will manufacture the 130-seat |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1993/1993%20-%201457.html |accessdate=October 10, 2018 |issn=0015-3710}} === 1995 === [[File:B-2 Spirit at Le Bourget Airport.JPEG|thumb|A stealth [[B-2 Spirit]] in 1995]] The 41st Paris Air Show main attraction was the stealth [[B-2 Spirit]] bomber, along with the [[Tupolev Tu-160]] and [[Sukhoi Su-32]] bombers.{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/12/business/worldbusiness/12iht-show.html |title= U.S. Bomber Steals the Paris Air Show |author= Barry James |date= June 12, 1995 |work= The New York Times}} The flying display included the [[Bell-Boeing V-22]] tilt-rotor, the [[Airbus Beluga]] Super Transporter, the [[Eurofighter 2000]], the [[Rockwell-MBB X-31]] high-manoeuvrability fighter demonstrator, the [[McDonnell Douglas C-17]] military transport, the [[Eurocopter EC135]] civil helicopter, the [[Sukhoi Su-35]] fighter, and the Daimler-Benz Aerospace [[Dornier 328]]-100, and for the first time on static the [[Boeing 777]], [[Saab Gripen]], [[Atlas Cheetah]] Mirage and [[Cessna Citation X]].{{cite news |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/preparing-for-paris-26725/ |title= Preparing |date=June 25 - July 1, 1997 |volume=151 |issue=4579 |page=10 |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1997/1997%20-%201654.html?search=Bombardier |accessdate=October 11, 2018 |date=September 21, 2007}}{{cite news |last1=Johnsson |first1=Julie |title=Airbus lands big orders as Paris Air Show opens |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24695559/orders_for_airbus_i/ |accessdate=October 20, 2018 |work=Chicago Tribune |date=June 19, 2007 |page=sec. 3, 1}}{{cite news | last1=Johnsson |first1=Julie |title=Airbus: Purchases may signal turmoil's end |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24695559/orders_for_airbus_i/ |accessdate=October 20, 2018 |work=Chicago Tribune |date=June 19, 2007 |page=sec. 3, 6}}. A mockup of the [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II|Lockheed Martin Joint Strike Fighter]]{{cite web |last1=Pocock |first1=Chris |title=F-35 Joint Strike Program Proceeds Apace |url=https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/2007-06-27/f-35-joint-strike-fighter-program-proceeds-apace |website=AINonline |publisher=Convention News Co., Inc. |accessdate=October 20, 2018 |date=June 27, 2007}} was on display. The [[Israel Aerospace Industries|IAI]] [[IAI Eitan|Heron TP]] [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|UAV]]{{cite web |title=Heron TP (Eitan) |url=http://defense-update.com/products/e/eitan-UAV.htm |website=Defense Update, International, Online Defense Magazine |publisher=Defense Update |accessdate=October 20, 2018 |date=July 17, 2011}} is ready to enter production. The Spanish steer-by-leaning AN-1 AeroQuad flying platform from Aeris Naviter weighed only 100 kilograms.{{cite web |last1=Walters |first1=Brian |title=Easy-to-fly AeroQuad uses a coaxial rotor |url=https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/2007-06-26/easy-fly-aeroquad-uses-coaxial-rotor |website=AINonline |publisher=Convention News Co., Inc. |accessdate=October 17, 2018 |date=June 26, 2007}} === 2009 === [[File:Salon du Bourget 20090619 238.jpg|thumb|Airbus A300 ZERO-G in 2009]] The 48th International Paris Air Show took place in 2009 and marked a hundred years of technological innovation in aeronautics and space conquest. The event was held from 15 to 21 June, at Le Bourget. A memorial service was held for the victims of [[Air France Flight 447]].{{cite web |url=http://alphasite.airfrance.com/s01/press-releases/?L=1 |title=Religious ceremonies for the victims of flight AF 447 |publisher=[[Air France]]|date=2009-06-05|access-date=2009-06-12}} ===2011=== [[File:A380 - Paris Air Show 2011 - Take off.jpg|thumb|A380 takes off for the crowds, 2011]] The 2011 show was the 49th presentation, and hosted over {{formatnum: 2100}} international exhibitors in 28 international pavilions. A total of 150 aircraft were on display, including the solar-electric aircraft [[Solar Impulse]].{{cite web|url=http://www.salon-du-bourget.fr/fr|title=Salon du Bourget 15/21 juin 2015|author=|date=|work=salon-du-bourget.fr|access-date=13 June 2015}} A demo A380 was damaged the day before the exhibition opened and needed a replacement;[http://lci.tf1.fr/france/faits-divers/2011-06/info-tf1-news-un-a380-percute-un-batiment-au-salon-du-bourget-6541227.html Un A380 heurte un bâtiment au Bourget ("A380 clips a building")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622113536/http://lci.tf1.fr/france/faits-divers/2011-06/info-tf1-news-un-a380-percute-un-batiment-au-salon-du-bourget-6541227.html |date=2011-06-22 }}, ''TF1 News'', 19 juin 2011.[http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises-finance/services/transport-logistique/20110620trib000630629/l-a380-volera-tout-de-meme-au-salon-du-bourget.html L'A380 volera tout de même au salon du Bourget ("A380 will still fly at Paris Air Show")], ''La Tribune'', 20 juin 2011. while the new [[Airbus A400M Atlas]] military transport aircraft had an engine failure, but could still perform some demonstration flights. ===2015=== The 2015 show, held from June 15 to June 21, 2015, saw the new [[Dassault Falcon 8X]], [[Airbus A350 XWB]] and [[Bombardier CS300]] and received 351,584 visitors, 2,303 exhibitors over 122,500 [[square metre]]s of exhibition space, 4,359 journalists from 72 countries and 130 billion euros in purchases and "cemented its position as the world's largest event dedicated to the aerospace industry".{{cite web |url= http://www.cimaya.fr/flipbook/SIAE-bilan2015-gb/ |title= 2015 Show report |publisher= GIFAS |date=}} During the show, Airbus Helicopters announced a successor to the [[Eurocopter AS332 Super Puma|Super Puma]], called the [[Airbus Helicopters X6]].[http://aviationweek.com/paris-air-show-2015/airbus-reveals-super-puma-successor Airbus Reveals Super Puma Successor] ===2017=== [[File:Paris Air Show 2017 Airbus racer (cropped).jpg|thumb|[[Airbus Helicopters X3]]-derived RACER model, 2017]] The 52nd Air Show was held from 19 to 25 June 2017, with 2,381 exhibitors from 48 countries, showing 140 aircraft including for the first time the [[Airbus A321neo]], [[Airbus A350-1000]], [[Boeing 787-10]], [[Boeing 737 MAX 9]], [[Kawasaki P-1]], [[Mitsubishi MRJ90]] and [[Lockheed Martin F-35]]. Inaugurated by French President [[Emmanuel Macron]], it was visited by 290 official delegations from 98 countries and 7 international organizations, French Prime Minister [[Edouard Philippe]], 3,450 journalists, 142,000 trade visitors and 180,000 general public visitors. Announcements for 934 commercial aircraft orders and purchasing commitments were worth a catalogue value of US$115 billion.{{Cite press release |url= https://www.siae.fr/Data/ElFinder/s4/SIAE-2017/communique%20presse/PR-52nd-International-Paris-Air-Show-2017-UK.pdf |title= 52nd International Paris Air Show Paris-Le Bourget 19-25 June 2017 |date= 28 June 2017 |publisher= GIFAS}} There were 1,226 order and commitments : 352 firm orders, 699 letters of intent or memorandums of understanding, 40 options and 135 options letters of intent; plus 229 conversions of existing orders, mainly for the Boeing [[737-10]] MAX variant launched at the show. There were mainly [[Narrow-body aircraft|narrowbodies]] with 1,021 orders or commitments against 76 [[Wide-body aircraft|widebodies]], 48 [[regional jet]]s and 81 [[turboprop]] airliners. With 766, mainly preliminary deals, [[Boeing]] led [[Airbus]] with 331, while [[Bombardier Aerospace]] had 64, [[Embraer]] 48 and [[ATR Aircraft]] 17. Nearly half of those order and commitments was from [[aircraft lessor]]s with 513, and where the operator was known, 43% came from Asia-Pacific, 27% from the middle east, 10% from Europe as from South America, 7% from Africa and 3% from North America.{{cite web |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/asset/17782 |title= Aircraft orders report - Paris Air Show 2017 |work= Flightglobal |date= June 2017}} ===2019=== The 53rd Air Show will be held from 17 to 23 June 2019. == Accidents == Among major accidents, there were two crashes of [[Convair B-58 Hustler]] bombers, in 1961 (during [[aerobatics]]) and 1965 (during landing).E. F. Rybak, J. Gruszczyński: ''Convair B-58 Hustler. Cz.II'', in: Nowa Technika Wojskowa 3/1999, p. 38 (in [[Polish language|Polish]]) In 1969, the crash of a [[FH-1100|Fairchild-Hiller FH-1100]] helicopter at Le Bourget killed the pilot.{{cite news |agency=AP |title=Pilot Killed As Copter Crashes at Paris Show |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23906075/pilot_killed_1969/ |work=Cincinnati Enquirer |date=June 6, 1969 |location=Ohio, Cincinnati |page=38|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 20, 2018}} {{Open access}} Another pilot was killed in the 1977 crash of a [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|Fairchild A-10]]. === 1973 crash === {{Main|1973 Paris Air Show crash}} At the Paris Air Show on June 3, 1973, the second [[Tupolev Tu-144]] production aircraft ([[aircraft registration|registration]] SSSR-77102) crashed during its display. It stalled while attempting a rapid climb. Trying to pull out of the subsequent dive, the aircraft broke up and crashed, destroying 15 houses and killing all six on board and eight on the ground; a further sixty people received serious injuries. The cause of this accident remains controversial. Theories include: the Tu-144 climbed to avoid a French Mirage [[chase plane]] whose pilot was attempting to photograph it; that changes had been made by the ground engineering team to the auto-stabilisation circuits to allow the Tu-144 to outperform the [[Concorde]] in the display circuit; and that the crew were attempting a manoeuvre and to outshine the Concorde. === 1989 === A [[Mikoyan MiG-29]] crashed during a demonstration flight with no loss of life. === 1999 === A [[Sukhoi Su-30MKI]] crashed during a demonstration flight with no loss of life. == See also == {{Portal|Paris|Aviation}} * [[Farnborough Airshow|Farnborough International Airshow]] * [[ILA Berlin Air Show]] * [[Aero India]] * [[EAA AirVenture Oshkosh]] == References == ;Notes {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} {{Commons-inline|bullet=none|Category:Paris Air Show 2007|2007 Paris Air Show}} * [http://www.gifas.asso.fr GIFAS, organisers of the Paris Air Show] {{International airshows}} {{Visitor attractions in Paris}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Arms fairs]] [[Category:Air shows]] [[Category:Trade fairs in France]] [[Category:Aviation in France]] [[Category:1909 establishments in France]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1909]] [[Category:Biennial events]] [[Category:Events in Paris]]

<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[File:Eriksson-Krohg-400x257.jpg|240px|right|thumbnail|Original [[painting]] [[Leif Eriksson|"Leif Eriksson Discovers America"]] by [[Christian Krohg]] was subject for the Norwegian championship online manipulation contest.]] --> A '''Photoshop contest''', or sometimes '''Photoshop battle''', is an [[online]] game, in which a [[website]] or user of an [[Internet forum]] will post a starting [[image]] — usually a [[photograph]] — and ask others to manipulate the image using some kind of [[computer graphics|graphics]] editing [[software]], such as [[Adobe Photoshop]], [[Corel Photo-Paint]], The [[GIMP]], [[PaintShop Pro]], [[Paint.NET]] or [[Paint (software)|Microsoft Paint]]. People can also use [[video editing]] software to create these images, such as [[Adobe Premiere Pro]] or [[VideoPad Video Editor|NCH VideoPad]].
While [[Photoshop (verb)|Photoshop]] is the industry standard image editing program, [[Adobe Systems]], the publisher of Photoshop, [[Adobe Photoshop#Cultural impact|discourages use]] of "Photoshop" to refer to anything other than their photo editing software, to prevent their [[trademark]] from becoming [[Generic trademark|generic]].
==Humor== <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:Lukket-50s-computer-HOAX.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Photoshopped "early computing" hoax, [http://forums.fark.com/cgi/fark/comments.pl?IDLink=1115586&tt=voteresults&ok=1 winner] of a photoshop contest [[Fark.com]], by user "lukket"; this image even fooled news publications as to its authenticity.]] --> A large part of the humor in many of these contests involves the use of [[internet meme]]s.
Such contests have recently seen increasing participation on many blogs and forums. The popular internet community [[Reddit]] has a community called /r/photoshopbattles devoted to the contests.
A more "underground" variety of these image manipulation jokes involves the blending of celebrity faces with nude or [[pornography|pornographic]] images, often combined with references to movies, music, magazines and other forms of related [[popular culture]].
==Photoshop tennis== '''Photoshop tennis''' (also known as '''Photoshop Pong''' or '''Photoshop battle''' (similar in its function to a "[[Turntablism#Turntablist contests|DJ battle]]" in [[hip hop music]]) is a game played through sequential alternating photoshopping of an [[image]]. Photoshop tennis originated in graphics-related [[internet forum]]s in the late-1990s/early-2000s, and shares an earlier history with online image games such as [[SITO]]'s "PANIC" (started January, 1994).<ref name="SITOpanic">[http://www.sito.org/docs/tennis.html SITO Panic and Photoshop Tennis]</ref> The game was made popular by art director Jim Coudal in 2001 as "Photoshop Tennis".<ref name="wiredtennis"/> The matches on coudal.com have since been renamed '''Layer Tennis''',<ref name="layertennis">[http://www.layertennis.com/ Coudal Partners' Layer Tennis]</ref> as they are no longer restricted to the use of Adobe Photoshop.
Each match of Photoshop tennis is generally played with two competing players.<ref name="wiredtennis">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2001/09/47132 |title=Anyone for Photoshop Tennis? |accessdate=2007-10-27 |last=Schreve |first=Jenn |date=2001-09-27 |publisher=[[Wired News]] }}</ref> The players pick a starting image, or one is "served" by a player, then another player makes some sort of alteration to the image in any chosen image editor (matches are not exclusive to Adobe Photoshop). They then send the altered image to the other player or players, usually via [[e-mail]] or by posting the image to a Photoshop tennis forum, who then edits that image and sends it back to the first player. This process goes back and forth until a predetermined number of rounds have elapsed, or the players otherwise wish to end the game. When the final round is over, there may be an independent [[judge]] who determines who has played the best shots, and declares that person the winner, or players may play without a clear winner. Sometimes extra rules can be enforced, such as sticking to one particular [[Computer software|software package]], or keeping to a particular [[Motif (visual arts)|theme]]. <!-- // Context of this sentence? It's not exclusive to any one forum: Posts have been known to be deleted by moderators even though the "Vote" option has been turned off. An example of Photoshop Tennis can be viewed [http://www.unicyclist.com/forums/showthread.php?t=57080 on the unicyclist forums.] // -->
==Pictures== <gallery> File:Kitrone.jpg|[[Photomontage]] made using [[GIMP]]. File:Wikipedia - taste the fruit of knowledge.jpg|[[Détournement]] of [[Jacob Jordaens]]' ''The Fall of Man'', made using [[GIMP]]. File:Photomontage (Forggensee Panorama) -2.jpg|A landscape photo composited and manipulated in [[Photoshop]]. File:SqueezeSponge.jpg|Photos composited and manipulated in [[Photoshop]]. </gallery>
==See also== * [[Adobe Photoshop]] * [[Photomontage]] * [[E-mail art]] * [[Fark.com]] * [[Photo editing (disambiguation)]] * [[Something Awful]]'s "Photoshop Phriday" * [[Worth1000]] * [[FreakingNews]]
